thread.title: High speed rail must come to North East at same time as rest of the country, campaigners say

author: Graeme Whitfield
title: High speed rail must come to North East at same time as rest of the country, campaigners say
text:
High speed rail must come to North East at same time as rest of the country, campaigners say Journeys from Newcastle to Birmingham in under two hours could be possible under planned rail improvements Share Sunderland Central MP Julie Elliott (Image: handout) Share Get business updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! A high-speed rail network in the North of England must be delivered at the same time as the planned HS2 line to help close the North-South divide, a powerful group of business and political leaders will say today. 
The Northern Powerhouse Partnership has won backing from around the region for a plan that would see train journeys from Newcastle to Birmingham reduced to just under two hours and Newcastle to London to two-and-a-quarter. Part of the proposed route for the HS2 high speed rail scheme (Image: PA) 
The group - which was set up by former Chancellor George Osborne - says Northern Powerhouse Rail would create thousands of jobs in the North, but must be delivered at the same time as the Government’s current high speed rail plan, which will deliver huge benefits to the Midlands and the south but will not come to the North East. 
The group’s call for a proper high speed rail service across the North comes as business and political leaders have come together in the region to push the case for improved investment in rail services outside of the capital. 
Today will also see Sunderland Central MP Julie Elliott delivering a keynote speech at a conference in Leeds to launch a campaign for better rail services to Sunderland, arguing that the full benefits of high speed rail must come to smaller cities and towns in the North as well as regional capitals. Read More Young entrepreneur opens Witchdoctor clinic to provide pain relief 
Ms Elliott said: “Delivering Northern Powerhouse Rail to cities and towns like Sunderland, Carlisle, Middlesbrough and Preston is the right aspiration for the Northern Powerhouse to get the maximum productivity benefits from this extension to the UK’s high-speed rail network beyond what HS2 will provide. Driving the North’s ambitions is a national priority. 
“The economic assets of Sunderland in key sectors like digital can be fully realised when fellow Northern cities like Leeds are part of the same ecosystem – genuinely collaborating, not competing.” 
Backers of Northern Powerhouse Rail say it would reduce rail journeys from Newcastle to Leeds to an hour, while journeys to cities like Bradford and Hull would also be considerably quicker. Read More Why the STEM agenda is so important to our North East firms 
The scheme received fresh impetus last year after a backlash to Transport Secretary Chris Grayling’s decision to downgrade rail improvement plans in the North just days before giving the green light to a multi-billion transport scheme in London. 
Northern Powerhouse Partnership vice-chair Lord Jim O’Neill said: “Getting Northern Powerhouse Rail delivered to the recommendations of Transport for the North is crucial for the success of the Northern Powerhouse. 
“Without connecting as quickly and efficiently as possible the many closely-located towns and cities of the Northern Powerhouse, it will not be able to create the agglomeration benefits that would transform the economy of the UK, never mind just the North. Read More 34,000-tonne monster ship The Albatross docks at the Port of Blyth 
“Indeed by doing it, the financial investment justification for central government would vastly exceed the usual cautious value for money criteria, and be one of the most exciting things for post Brexit Britain, notably for an area that has many disillusioned voters.” 
The Northern Powerhouse Partnership argues that a high speed rail link around the North would also benefit young people wanting to study in the region and provide better links for companies wanting to develop overseas trade. Like us on Facebook
